Fig. 1 TEM images of the synthesized Co3O4 catalysts (a); HRTEM images of the synthesized Co3O4 catalysts (b, c); Wide-angle XRD patterns of the synthesized Co3O4 catalysts (d). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 The high resolution XPS spectra for O1s and Co2p of the Co3O4 catalysts (a); CO-TPD and H2-TPR profiles of Co3O4 nanorods. 60 mg Co3O4 catalysts were pretreated with a stream of 20 vol.% O2/N2 gas mixture at 450 °C for 30 min (b). The catalysts were heated from 50 °C to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Low-magnification (a), high-magnification SEM images (b) and large area elemental mapping of metallic monolithic catalysts (c); Low-magnification SEM images (d, e) and elemental mapping of cordierite monolithic catalysts (f). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of the metallic monolithic catalysts (Insert: BJH pore diameter distribution) (a); Influence of ultrasonic vibration, thermal shock and reaction process on the washcoat adhesion of metallic monolithic catalysts (b). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 In-situ DRIFTS of Co3O4 nanorods catalysts for (a)1 vol.% CO/15 vol.% O2/N2 balanced co-adsorption and reaction; (b) 1 vol.% CO/N2 balanced adsorption at 25 °C. The samples were pretreated by 20 vol.%O2/N2 at 450 °C for 30 min, then cooled down to room temperature. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 In-situ DRIFTS of Co3O4 nanorods catalysts for (a) 1 vol.% CO/15 vol.% O2/0.6 vol.% H2O/N2 balanced co-adsorption and reaction; (b) 1 vol.%CO/7 vol.% CO2/0.6 vol.%H2O/15 vol.%O2/N2 balanced co-adsorption and reaction. The samples were pretreated by 20 vol.%O2/N2 at 450 °C for 30 min, then cooled down to room temperature. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Proposed reaction routes suggested for nanorod-shaped Co3O4. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 CO conversion as a function of GHSV over cordierite and metallic monolithic catalysts. (Experimental conditions: 1%CO, 15%O2 and N2 balanced, H2O content ∼3 ppm, 220 °C, atmospheric pressure). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 CO conversion as a function of temperature over metallic monolithic catalysts at 25,000 h−1, 30,000 h−1, 45,000 h−1 and 60,000 h−1 respectively. (Experimental conditions: 0.5% CO, 15% O2 and N2 balanced, without H2O (a) and with 5.6 vol.% H2O (b)); (c) TOFs of CO oxidation over metallic monolithic catalysts with the existence of 5.6 vol% H2O at 25,000 h−1, 30,000 h−1, 45,000 h−1 and 60,000 h−1 respectively; (d)The corresponding Arrhenius plots for the reaction kinetics with the existence of 5.6 vol% H2O at 25,000 h−1, 45,000 h−1 and 60,000 h−1 respectively. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 cycling tests. (Experimental conditions: 0.5 vol.% CO, 15 vol.% CO2 and N2 balanced, GHSV = 30,000 h−1) (a), Stability tests of the monolithic catalyst under 7 vol.% CO2 and 5.6 vol.% H2O at space velocity of 25,000 h−1 and 35,000 h−1 respectively (b). (Experimental conditions: 1 vol.% CO, 15 vol.% CO2 and N2 balanced, 220 °C). Temperature-dependent reaction pathways of CO oxidation and the application as monolithic catalysts for Co3O4 nanorods Jia Li Yueyu Lei Zengzeng Guo Guanghua Li Xiaoyu Chen ⁎ Fubao Zhou ⁎ Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Fire Safety in Urban Underground Space, China University of Mining and Technology, Xuzhou, Jiangsu, 221116, People’s Republic of China Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Fire Safety in Urban Underground Space China University of Mining and Technology Xuzhou Jiangsu 221116 People’s Republic of China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Via investigating the evolution of carbonate intermediates by in-situ DRIFTS (25 °C–350 °C) analysis, temperature-dependent reaction pathways of CO oxidation over Co3O4 nanorods are successfully proposed. The types of reactive oxygen species participated in CO oxidation may affect the way CO react with neighboring oxygen atoms. Additionally, the negative effect of water and CO2 on the catalytic activity was also studied. Considering the remarkable reactivity towards CO, the Co3O4 catalysts were integrated onto metallic and cordierite monolithic substrates and used for CO conversion as application. SEM examinations show that the catalyst layer was coated on the substrates uniformly with few microcracks, and desirable mechanical shock and thermal shock resistance was observed. The influence of substrate materials, gas hourly space velocity, the existence of water vapor and CO2, and reaction time on the CO oxidation performance of monolithic catalysts was investigated. Metallic monolithic catalysts performed higher CO oxidation activity mainly owing to superior heat conductivity and larger surface area compared with cordierite monolithic catalysts. It is noticeable that superior activity was also achieved under high gas flow with the existence of H2O (5.6 vol.%) and CO2 (7 vol.%) at 220 °C, suggesting great promise for practical application. Keywords Co3O4 nanorods In-situ DRIFTS Carbonate intermediates Monolithic catalyst High gas flow CO oxidation 1 Introduction Catalytic oxidation has been proved as an economic and efficient method for CO oxidation to meet the increasingly stringent demands for CO control [1–5]. CO is colorless, odorless and highly toxic gas, and can lead to the occurrence of death owing to its strong affinity for hemoglobin in the blood [6–8]. Therefore, it is of profound significance to develop a practical and highly efficient monolithic catalyst for CO oxidation. Currently, catalytic oxidation method is extensively investigated for gas treatment, such as vehicle exhaust purification [9–12], preferential oxidation of carbon monoxide in hydrogen-rich gas in fuel cell technology [13–16], volatile organic compounds degradation [17–19]and so on [20–25]. The study of CO oxidation over solid catalysts has been of great interest due to the practical application for CO removal and the importance in understanding catalytic mechanisms [16–18]. Numerous catalysts with excellent CO oxidation performance have been proposed [19–25]. Noble metal catalysts perform excellent activity towards CO oxidation at low temperature and a moderate amount of water can even promote the catalytic activity. Noble metal-based monolithic catalysts are widely employed in purifying automobile emission, especially palladium and platinum-based catalysts [26–28]. The drawbacks of sintering at high temperature and high-cost for noble metal catalysts limits its practical application [1], while metal oxide catalysts, especially transition metal oxides, have been considered as promising alternatives with low cost and outstanding catalytic performance [29–32]. Hopcalite catalyst, the mixtures of manganese and copper oxides, has been widely used in submarines, refuge chamber and respirator [33]. Copper/ceria-based catalyst play an important role in CO removal of proton-exchange membrane fuel cells [15]. However, metal oxide catalysts are always deactivated by moisture [34]. Thus, desiccation process is required for the removal of water in the industrial application which increases the application cost. Considering the pressure drop in practical application, cordierite and metallic honeycomb monoliths are usually utilized as substrates for coating catalysts powder [35]. To sum up, desirable monolithic catalysts for CO oxidation should exhibit high catalytic activity as well as better tolerance towards H2O. Besides, high stability and durability are also necessary. Tricobalt tetroxide (Co3O4)-based catalysts have attracted much attention due to the high CO oxidation performance, as well as hydrocarbon oxidation and so on [29,35]. Co3O4 nanorods synthesized by Xie [36] shown extraordinarily-high CO oxidation activity even at temperature as low as −77 °C, and was employed as the CO oxidation catalysts in this study. Temperature is determining for its catalytic activity, especially with the existence of water and CO2. However, few studies were focused on the difference of reaction pathways at low and high temperature. In this paper, in-situ DRIFTS was employed for the further insight into the mechanism of CO oxidation over Co3O4 nanorods. Besides, deactivation process induced by CO2 and H2O was also studied. Some efforts were devoted to coating Co3O4 catalysts onto cordierite and metallic honeycomb monoliths with large specific surface area, low pressure drop and good mass/heat transfer through washcoating technique. The structures and morphologies of the monolithic catalysts were investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscope (SEM). Considering the practical application, the adhesive strength and influence of the moisture, CO2 and gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) on the catalytic activity were also investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Co3O4 powder preparation Nanorod-shaped Co3O4 catalysts were prepared by calcination at 450 °C of a cobalt hydroxide carbonate precursor obtained by the precipitation of cobalt acetate with sodium carbonate in ethylene glycol [36]. Typically, 4.98 g cobalt acetate [C4H14CoO8, 98%, Energy Chemical industry] was dissolved in 60 mL ethylene glycol [C2H6O2, 99%, Energy Chemical industry], and the mixture was heated to 160 °C. Then 200 mL 0.2 M Na2CO3 solution was added, followed by further aging for 1 h. The precipitate was filtered and washed with ethyl alcohol and distilled water for three times. The solid obtained was dried at 50 °C overnight under vacuum and calcined at 450 °C for 4 h in air. During the preparation, the solution and slurry were under vigorous stirring and protected by nitrogen stream. 2.2 Monolithic catalysts preparation 2.2.1 Pretreatment of substrates Commercial FeCrAl honeycomb (400cpsi) with 17 mm diameter and 50 mm length supplied by Nanjing Dingfeng Electric Alloy Materials Co., Ltd., China, was employed as the metallic substrate. The substrate was firstly cleaned in ultrasonic bath with acetone for 30 min and washed with the distilled water for the removal of impurities. Combined chemical and thermal treatment were adopted to pretreat the metallic substrates aiming to improve surface roughness level and chemical compatibility with the Co3O4 catalysts [37]. The honeycomb was immersed in 1 mol/L H2SO4 solution at 60 °C for 5 min, and heated to 1000 °C at 3 °C/min and kept for 10 h in air in muffle oven. Commercial cordierite honeycomb (400cpsi) with 18 mm diameter and 50 mm length supplied by Pingxiang Chemical Co., Ltd., China, was used as the ceramic substrate. The ceramic substrate was washed in ultrasonic bath with acetone for 30 min and washed with the distilled water for the removal of impurities as mentioned above. 2.2.2 Synthesis of structured catalysts The Co3O4 catalysts were coated onto the monoliths by washcoating technique. The slurries of catalysts were prepared by mixing 10 wt.% Co3O4 catalysts and 3 wt.% silica-sol (20 wt.%, pH = 9) as additives with distilled water. Then monoliths were immersed in the slurries and kept for 5 min, and extracted slowly. Monoliths were blown with the air to remove the excess of slurry, and dried at 60 °C for 2 h under vacuum. This process was repeated many times until the desired catalysts coating on the substrates was achieved. Finally, the structured catalysts were calcined at 450 °C in air for 4 h. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images of the synthesized Co3O4 catalysts were recorded by using a Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV and 5 kV respectively. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts power were carried out using a BRUKER D8 Advance diffractometer with monochromated Cu-Kα radiation source and the peaks were compared to standards published by JCPDS data. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on a Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250Xi was employed to study the surface composition and electronic states of the Co3O4 catalyst. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), CO-temperature programmed desorption (CO-TPD) and CO pulse chemisorption were performed on an AutoChem II 2920. Prior to the TPR measurement, the samples were pretreated at 450 °C for 2 h, followed by cooling to room temperature. The 5% H2/He gas mixture was introduced at the flow rate of 30 mL/min with the heating rate of 10 °C /min. The samples used for CO-TPD experiments were also pretreated at 450 °C in pure N2 atmosphere for 2 h, and the 10%CO/N2 gas mixture was introduced at 30 mL/min with the heating rate of 10 °C/min. The in-situ DRIFTS experiments were performed on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer. Prior to measurements, Co3O4 catalysts were pretreated in 20 vol.% O2/N2 of 50 ml/min at 450 °C for 30 min, then cooled down to room temperature. CO pulse chemisorption, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and scanning electron microscope (SEM) were employed to study the characterization of monolithic catalysts. 6 mm☓6 mm slices cut from the monolithic catalyst were used as samples. The CO pulse chemisorption was operated at 50 °C with He as carrier gas of 50 mL/min. Before measurement, the samples were reduced under 10 vol.% H2/Ar flow at 500 °C for 2 h, subsequently cooled down to room temperature. 10 vol.% CO/Ar pulses (5 mL) were injected to the samples until a saturation of CO adsorption. The Co dispersion was calculated on the basis of the CO-Co chemisorption stoichiometry of 1. The N2 adsorption-desorption measurement was carried out by Quantachrome NOVA 1000 Gas Sorption Analyzer to detect the textural properties of the samples at 77 K. The samples were degassed at 450 °C for 3 h firstly. The specific surface area for the monolithic catalysts were calculated by Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) equations, and the pore size distribution was calculated using the Barrett-Jovner-Halenda (BJH) formula. The surface morphologies and elements distribution of the monolithic catalysts was observed by scanning electron microscope (SEM), using JEOL 6335 F. 2.4 Testing of the catalytic activity and kinetic data The cohesive ability of the monolithic catalysts was firstly tested by ultrasonic vibration. The samples were immersed in petroleum ether and treated with ultrasonic bath (50 kHz/180 W) for 30 min, then taken out, dried at 80 °C under vacuum for 2 h and weighted. Besides, the thermal shock treatment was also employed to test the cohesive stability of the samples. The samples were heated to 500 °C and kept for 1 h in a muffle furnace, then taken out and exposed in air directly until their temperature became room temperature and weighted. The impact force originating from high gas flow will induce the fall off of catalyst layer. Aiming to measure the cohesive ability of the monolithic catalysts under high gas flow, the mass losses of catalysts after about 30 h application were tested. The catalytic activity of synthesized monolithic catalysts was measured in a fixed bed quartz flow reactor with a quartz tube cell (19 mm inner-diameter) as shown in the Fig. S1 (Supporting Information). The samples, wrapped with silica wool to cover the gap between the samples and tube cell, were fixed in the center of quartz tube. K-type thermocouple in contact with the bottom of the samples was employed to monitor the temperature of monolithic catalysts. The specific feed stream was prepared by mixing the pure gas with the mass gas flow meters and a gas mixer, and the ratio of GHSV to gas flow are 78.6 and 88.2 for ceramic monolith and metallic monolith respectively. Before measurements, the samples were pretreated at 450 °C for 30 min under the stream of 20 vol.% O2/N2 gas mixture, then cooled down to room temperature. After reactant gas introduced, the catalysts bed was stabilized at a given temperature for 5 min, then the outlet gas was measured by an online gas chromatograph. Water vapor was supplied by a syringe pump through a vaporizer. Due to the gas quantity over the limitation of the gas chromatography, another mass flow meter was used to split the gas flow. The CO conversion was calculated according to the following equation. CO conversion % = CO in − CO out CO in × 100 % Where [CO]in is the CO concentration at inlet and [CO]out is the CO concentration at outlet. The reaction rates (mol/(g.s)), Arrhenius plots for the reaction rate constants and TOFs (s−1) of the metallic monolithic catalysts under different GHSV were achieved by adjusting CO conversion below 15% with a feed gas of 0.5 vol.% CO/15% vol.% O2/N2 balanced under dry or moisture-rich (5.6 vol.%) conditions. The TOFs (s−1) was calculated by the following equation. T O F = [ C O ] i n * X C O * V * M C o M C O * D C o * W c Where [CO]in is the CO concentration at inlet, XCO is the CO conversion, V is the velocity of gas flow, MCo and MCO is molar mass of Co and CO respectively, DCo is the value of Co dispersion and WC is the mass of coated catalysts. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization The TEM image of the synthesized Co3O4 catalyst is shown in the Fig. 1 a, and the HRTEM images are displayed in the Fig. 1b and c. Small nanorods can be observed with diameter of 5–15 nm and length of 100–300 nm. (111) and (220) planes with interplanar spacing of 0.467 nm and 0.286 nm respectively can be obviously identified. The XRD patterns of samples (Fig. 1d) are analyzed (PDF2 entry 42-1467). No characteristic peaks corresponding to impurities is observed. The surface composition and elemental states of the synthesized Co3O4 nanorods were measured by XPS analysis as shown in the Fig. 2 a. The XPS spectra of the O1s displays three major peaks located at the binding energies (BEs) of 530 eV, 531.3 eV and 532.3 eV respectively, which are accordingly assigned to the characteristic surface lattice oxygen (Oα), surface adsorbed oxygen (Oβ) and the oxygen in water or surface carbonate (Oγ). The atomic ratios of Oα, Oβ and Oγ derived from the XPS analysis is listed in the Table 1 . The results show that the Oα accounted for about 43%, which is beneficial for CO oxidation. The Co2p spectra can be divided into three peaks of Co2+, Co3+ and satellites. The existence of Co2+ can be further confirmed by the appearance of satellites. The binding energy of Co2+ is about 780.9 eV and 794.9 eV, while the binding energy of Co3+ is about 779.8 eV and 796.4 eV. The relative Co3+/Co2+ atomic ratio acquired by the areas of peaks is about 1/3 as listed in the Table 1. H2-TPR measurement was employed to evaluate the redox behaviors of the synthesized Co3O4 nanorods as shown in the Fig. 2b, and three characteristic peaks are observed in the temperature range of 50–600 °C. A significant reduction peak around 105 °C is observed, which is attributed to the active species (surface oxygen adsorbed) on the catalysts surface formed during the pretreatment [38,39]. Compared with previous researches, this reduction peak is more intense [38,39] and much more hydrogen (0.32 mmol/g) is consumed, which is corresponded to the high CO oxidation performance of Co3O4 nanorods at low temperature (−77 °C). The other two main reduction bands are around 250 and 492°, which can be assigned to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and CoO to Co, respectively. The amount of hydrogen consumed by the low temperature reduction at 250 °C is 3.14 mmol/g, which is about one-third of that for the high temperature reduction (10.3 mmol/g), confirming the sequential transformation of Co3O4 to CoO and CoO to Co. CO-TPD measurement was employed to investigate the surface oxygen activity of the Co3O4 nanorods towards CO oxidation as shown in the Fig. 2b. The Co3O4 nanorods catalysts exhibit four desorption peaks. The largest peak appeared at around 91 °C is much lower than other Co3O4 catalysts [40–43], indicating that CO molecules can easily adsorb onto the catalysts surface and react rapidly with activated oxygen. Thus, the Co3O4 nanorods can exhibit extremely high oxidation performance. Fig. 3 (a–c) present the typical morphology of the metallic monolithic catalysts. The samples show compactly regular shapes of Co3O4 catalysts layer structure with few microcracks on the surface of metallic substrate as presented in the Fig. 3a. Plenty of mesopores and macropores are clearly observed in the high-magnification SEM image (Fig. 3b), which is crucial for the high CO oxidation performance by increasing specific surface area. The Co, O and Si distribution on the metallic monolithic catalysts surface was monitored by EDS as shown in the Fig. 3c, revealing that Co, O and Si are homogeneously distributed on the coating layer surface. The Co3O4 catalysts account for about 86.14 wt.% of the catalyst surface. Fig. 3(d–f) present the typical morphologies of cordierite monolithic catalysts. SEM images of cross-section of the cordierite monolithic catalyst are displayed in the Fig. 3 (e, f). It is clear that a catalyst layer with about 3.4 μm was achieved as presented in the Fig. 3d. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm of the metallic monolithic catalysts was obtained to assess the pore structures and specific surface area of the samples. The metallic monolithic catalysts present a typical IV shape isotherm with H3 hysteresis pattern, which is a characteristic of mesoporous materials as shown in the Fig. 4 a. The BET specific surface area of the as-synthesized metallic monolithic catalysts is 14 m2 g−1, which is much smaller than that of Co3O4 nanorods (117 m2 g−1) as listed in the Table 1. BJH pore size distribution curve mostly shows mesopores (10–50 nm), and some macropores (>50 nm) are also observed (insert of Fig. 4a), which is further confirmed by the SEM analysis. The pore diameter and pore volume are summarized in Table 1. Co dispersion on the metallic monolithic catalysts was measured by CO chemisorption as shown in the Fig. S2. The CO chemical adsorption amounts for the samples is 0.342 mL/gcat, and the sample exhibits very low Co dispersion of 2.1% and Co3O4 catalysts dispersion of 2.9% accordingly. The washcoat adhesion is crucial for the reliable performance of monolithic catalysts in practical application. After three dip-coating steps, about 9.7% and 3.3% of the Co3O4 catalysts were coated on the cordierite and metallic substrates, respectively (Table 1). As shown in the Fig. 4b, the total mass losses of the metallic and cordierite monolithic catalysts were less than 5 wt.% after the ultrasonic vibration and thermal shock treatments. This indicates the catalysts anchored onto the substrates tightly, owing to the combination of chemical and thermal treatment. Besides, after CO oxidation for about 30 h under high gas flow, the mass losses of the metallic monolithic catalyst were only about 1.8%, and this loss is mainly ascribed to the unavoidable force induced by the high gas flow. 3.2 Temperature-dependent reaction deactivation pathways of CO oxidation on Co3O4 nanorods As reported, the synthesized Co3O4 nanorods exhibited excellent CO oxidation performance even at extremely low temperature. Attempting to get insights into the CO oxidation mechanism for Co3O4 nanorods, in-situ DRIFTS analyses were carried out on different conditions. Besides, the deactivation process induced by the existence of CO2 and H2O was also investigated by in-situ DRIFTS at the temperature ranging from 25 °C to 350 °C. 3.2.1 In-situ DRIFTS study of the CO + O2 reaction and CO adsorption on Co3O4 catalysts The CO oxidation mechanism over Co3O4 nanorods catalysts was investigated comprehensively with temperature-resolved DRIFTS. After the pretreated catalysts cooled down to room temperature, a gas mixture of 1 vol.%CO/15 vol.%O2/N2 was introduced to samples cell, and the DRIFTS were recorded from 25 °C to 350 °C. The Fig. 5 a shows the in-situ DRIFTS of co-adsorption of CO and O2 on Co3O4 catalysts. The bands at 2340–2345, and 2376–2378 cm−1 are assigned to stretching vibration of the OCO bond, suggesting the formation of CO2 [29,44]. Faint change is observed for the bands intensity with temperature increasing as presented in Table S1, in accordance with the fact that 100% conversion for CO oxidation is given at room temperature. Bands between 2100–2200 cm−1, ascribed to Co-carbonyl species [29,45], are negligible even at room temperature. This may be attributed to simultaneous adsorption of CO on active sites and their neighboring active oxygen (O* + CO* → CO2 ծ-) [46]. The bands between 1000 to 1800 cm−1 illustrate the reaction mechanism of the catalytic reaction in details by monitoring carbonate-type species [47]. At low temperature (<200 °C), the spectra mainly contain two intense bands at 1385 and 1047cm−1, which are the characteristic vibrations of surface monodentate carbonate species [46,48]. At high temperature (>200 °C), peaks at 1047, 1288 and 1550 cm−1 are dominant and characteristic vibrations of surface bidentate carbonate species [45,46,48]. The difference of carbonate intermediates at low and high temperature may be ascribed for the variety of active oxygen species participated in CO oxidation. As reported previously [49], superoxide species (O2-) weakly bound with Co3O4 are easily formed on the catalysts surface and act as main oxidants for CO oxidation at low temperature, which may be in a good accordance with the characteristic reduction peak around 105 °C of TPR shown in Fig. 2b. Adsorbed CO prefers to react with atomic oxygen anion supplied by the superoxide species to form monodentate carbonate species which give rise to CO2 subsequently (-O2-+ 2−CO → 2CO2). At high temperature, surface oxygen ion (O-) become the main oxidants, considering superoxide species desorb easily proposed by O2-TPD investigation [49]. Without the absence of supplied atomic oxygen anion, CO adsorbed on active sites glides towards the surface oxygen, forming bidentate carbonate species and releasing CO2 (-O- + −CO → CO2). Besides, time-resolved DRIFTS, obtained by introducing a gas mixture of 1 vol.%CO /N2 to samples cell, was used to study CO adsorption process on pretreated Co3O4 nanorods at room temperature as shown in Fig. 5b. It is noteworthy that CO2 was formed without any gaseous oxygen in the stream in 20 min. This observation confirms the existence of abundant active oxygen species on the peroxided catalysts surface. The two peaks at 2117 and 2171 cm−1 are attributed to gas-phase CO. Vibrational peak intensities of adsorbed CO with time are shown in Fig. S3. The quick increase is observed initially, indicating CO conversion drops rapidly. Considering the weak band at 1385 cm−1 and intense band at 1543 cm−1 assigned to bidentate carbonate species, the most of active oxygen species consumed for CO oxidation is O-. This observation demonstrates that O- is reactive to CO at room temperature and the amount of O- is much larger than O2-, which is in accordance with previous investigation. 3.2.2 In-situ DRIFTS study of the CO + O2+H2O and CO + O2+H2O + CO2 reaction on Co3O4 catalysts The DRIFTS recording process was same as that presented in 3.2.1 but the reactants were replaced with gas mixture of 1 vol.%CO/0.6 vol.%H2O/15 vol.%O2/N2 and 1 vol.%CO/0.6 vol.%H2O/15 vol.%O2/7 vol.%CO2/N2 respectively. When 0.6% water is injected to the above system, apart from the bands around 3400 cm−1 as shown in the Fig. S4, there is also a water band emerged at 1631 cm−1 shown in Fig. 6 a. The addition of water weakens the peaks of surface monodentate carbonate species at low temperature probably by suppressing the activity of active oxygen species, thus reducing the catalytic activity of Co3O4. Interestingly, the bands attribute to CO2 are visible even under moisture-rich conditions, in agreement with water-resistance of Co3O4 nanorods reported. However, the curves are similar to those of dry condition when temperature was over 200 °C shown in Fig. S4, because the negative effect of water can be ignored at high temperature. At last, when additional CO2 (7%) as well as 0.6% water are added, a conspicuous band around 1498 cm−1 appears at low temperature as shown in the Fig. 6b. This band can be identified as the formation of hydrogen carbonate (and other two characteristic bands for hydrogen carbonate around 1220 and 1650 cm−1 may be covered) which further reduces surface active oxygen species and blocks active sites [50]. It is noticeable that the band assigned to surface monodentate carbonate species is almost invisible, indicating the existence of hydrogen carbonate would deactivate Co3O4 catalysts completely. These may be the most significant difference compared with the CO2 absence catalytic oxidation on wet condition. 3.2.3 CO oxidation mechanism proposed Through the in-situ DRIFTS studies, we suggest the CO oxidation over Co3O4 nanorods follows the Mars van Krevelen mechanisms. In summary, the proposed reaction routes are presented in Fig. 7 in black lines. The excellent activity of the nanorod Co3O4 at low temperature can be attributed to the robust vitality of abundant superoxide species (O2 −) on catalysts surface. However, at high temperature, CO is mainly oxidized by surface oxygen ion (O-), as the surface oxygen ion of Co3O4 is more stable than superoxide species and may form a bidentate carbonate intermediate by reacting with adsorbed CO. The reaction of active oxygen species (O2- and O-) and CO gives rise to CO2 and leaves vacancy sites, which can be further refilled by adsorbed O2. Water may affect the catalytic activity at low temperature, and the existence of CO2 can even hinder the oxidation by forming hydrogen carbonate, corresponded to the CO conversion curves of the catalysts (Fig. 7 red lines). Nevertheless, the desorption of hydroxy and hydrogen carbonate at high temperature ensures the catalytic performance. 3.3 Catalytic performance of monolithic catalyst 3.3.1 The influence of GHSV The comparison experiments of CO oxidation ability for synthesized cordierite and metallic monolithic catalysts at different GHSV were performed, in order to further investigate the influence of substrate materials on catalytic performance. The monolithic catalysts were regenerated with a 20 vol.% O2/N2 gas mixture at 450 °C for 30 min before tests. The CO conversion curves of cordierite and metallic monolithic catalysts at different GHSV at 220 °C are shown in the Fig. 8 . 100% conversion is achieved at 60,000 h−1 for metallic monolithic catalysts, while about 48% conversion is achieved for cordierite monolithic catalysts at the same conditions. The difference in catalytic performances suggests that the catalysts coated onto metallic monolith exhibit the higher catalytic activity and the properties of substrates have determining influence on the CO oxidation ability under high gas flow. Due to the existence of great temperature difference between gas mixture and monolithic catalysts, a considerable amount of heat from catalysts is carried away, which leads to the decrease of catalysts temperature and undoubted decline of CO oxidation ability. Hence, maintaining the monolithic catalysts at desired temperature under high gas flow is crucial for the highly-efficient CO purification. The capacity of conducting heat for used substrate materials are extremely important. Besides, large geometrical area is also of significant importance, which can ensure sufficient contact between the coated catalysts and the reactants. With larger void ratio, higher heat conductivity and better ability to support thermal shocks than ceramic monoliths [51,52], metallic monolith catalysts are destined to exhibit better CO oxidation capacity and metal substrates are the preferential candidates for application. 3.3.2 Catalytic activity and the reaction kinetics of CO oxidation The catalytic performance of the metallic monolithic catalysts evaluated in CO oxidation is shown in the Fig. 9 a. Excellent catalytic performances under large gas quantity are observed, and CO is fully converted into CO2 at 130 °C when GHSV below 30,000 h−1. The CO conversion at the same temperature drops with the GHSV increasing as expected, ascribed to lessening of contact time between catalysts and CO molecular and aggravation of thermal consuming. When GHSV reaching 60,000 h−1, the 100% conversion is achieved at 190 °C. It is noteworthy that the unfavorable influence of space velocity on catalytic performance is weak in the range of low GHSV while the influence became determining when the GHSV higher than threshold. The negative deactivating influence on catalytic performance induced by the H2O is observed as shown in the Fig. 9b. The metallic monolithic catalysts exhibit very low CO oxidation performance at low temperature (∼100 °C), and higher temperature is needed to achieved 100% conversion. The TOFs of the metallic monolithic catalysts at different GHSV are presented in the Fig. 9c. The overall TOFs become lower with the GHSV increasing, indicating that high gas flow will suppress the catalytic activity. The comparison of the TOFs between Co3O4 metallic monolithic catalysts and other catalysts reported are listed in the Table 2 . The TOFs of Co3O4 metallic monolithic catalysts are much lower than that of Co3O4 nanorods catalysts powder as expected. However, its TOFs are even higher than some reported noble metal catalysts powders, confirming the observed outstanding CO oxidation activity. The apparent activation energy of metallic monolithic catalysts for CO oxidation at the GHSV of 25,000 h−1, 45,000 h−1 and 60,000 h−1 were 32.1 kJ/mol, 52.2 kJ/mol and 79 kJ/mol respectively as shown in the Fig. 10 d, and increase with the GHSV increasing, suggesting that gas flow has significant effect on the CO oxidation performance of monolithic catalysts. In fact, the change of TOFs values and activation energies for various GHSV at the same temperature was mainly contributed by the strong effects of mass/heat transfer. High gas flow exhibited negative influence on the process of external and internal diffusion. The gas mixture at room temperature consumed lots of heat, thus resulting in the inhomogeneous distribution of temperature. The increasing GHSV would aggravate negative effect of mass/heat transfer on catalytic performance. Besides, the change of reaction mechanism would occur in the range of 100–150 °C with the existence of water as analyzed before, which could partly contribute to the change of TOFs values and activation energies at 130 °C. 3.3.3 The influence of CO2 and H2O and catalytic stability To investigate the negative effect of H2O and CO2 on CO oxidation over the metallic monolithic catalyst at different GHSV, 7 vol.% CO2 and 5.6 vol.% H2O were successively added in the feed stream as shown in the Fig. 10. The experimental results show that the metallic monolithic catalyst is hardly affected by the existence of H2O and CO2 when GHSV below 25,000 h−1 and CO is fully converted to CO2 at 220 °C. When the GHSV over 30,000 h−1, CO oxidation performance is slightly affected by the existence of CO2, this is mainly due to the competitive adsorption on active sites of catalyst between CO and CO2. With the coexistence of 7 vol.% CO2 and 5.6 vol.% H2O, the CO concentration in the outlet remained almost unchanged in 30 min when the GHSV below 25000 h−1, suggesting that the metallic monolithic catalyst exhibits extremely-high resistance to H2O and CO2 at 220 °C. The CO concentration in the outlet increase sharply when GHSV over a certain level. It is probably caused by the sharp accumulation of carbonates and/or bicarbonates and H2O/OH- species hindering the active sites for CO oxidation on the catalysts surface under large amount of water vapor and CO2 [29,36]. The catalytic durability and stability of metallic monolithic catalysts were measured. There is no significant change to the curves of temperature versus CO conversion even after five cycles as described in the Fig. 10a, demonstrating the metallic monolithic catalysts possess excellent stability which is vital to practical application. Besides, CO oxidation performance at 220 °C under 7 vol.% CO2 and 5.6 vol.% H2O was also conducted, with further investigation for the negative influence of CO2 and H2O. As for the GHSV of 25,000 h−1, the reaction gave 100% conversion for 5 h probably owing to the limited accumulation of carbonates and H2O/OH- species on the catalyst surface and the sufficient active sites for CO oxidation. However, the CO conversion of the metallic monolithic catalysts only maintained a high level (∼98%) for around 60 min, and then decreased to 90% in the following 240 min when the GHSV increased to 35000h−1. It could be ascribed to mass accumulation of carbonates and H2O/OH- species hindering active sites. Regenerated at 450 °C for 30 min, the monolithic catalysts would perform even better catalytic performance as shown in the Fig. 10b. 3.3.4 CO oxidation performance of monolithic catalyst in confined space Aiming to investigate the practical effect of Co3O4 monolithic catalyst manufactured above in confined space, a catalytic honeycomb reactor was manufactured as shown in the Fig. 11 . The monolithic catalyst was heated by heating tape, and its temperature was monitored via a K-type thermocouple. The stainless-steel tube was wrapped by quartz wool for heat preservation and insulation. An organic glass box (0.5 m ☓ 0.6 m ☓1m) was utilized as a confined space. A CO detector was fixed at the center of organic glass box, used for monitoring CO concentration. The air in the box was supplied from surrounding environment without further purification with the moisture content about 0.42 vol.%. A certain volume of 8 vol.%CO/N2 gas mixture was injected and the initial CO concentration in the box was about 4300 ppm. In the box, gas flows from the bottom to the top, forming a circulation. The catalytic honeycomb reactor, placed between the outlet and inlet, was the core component for CO oxidation. The motivation for gas flowing was provided by a gas pump. Prior to experiments, catalytic honeycomb reactor was pretreated at 450 °C for 30 min under a 20 vol.% O2/N2 stream. The temperature of monolithic catalyst was kept at 220 °C to avoid the deactivation induced by water. The CO oxidation performance of catalytic honeycomb reactor in confined space was investigated with the gas flow of 350 L/h and 550 L/h respectively as presented in Fig. 12 . At first the CO concentration declined to a desirable range within 3 h, suggesting high activity of Co3O4 monolithic catalyst for application in confined space. However, the decline rate decreased with time when CO concentration in the box was below 1000 ppm, probably attributed to diffusion effect. Gas outlet and inlet were set at the bottom and top of box respectively, leading to the difference of CO concentration at top and bottom of box. Thus, CO at the bottom of box diffuse to the top under the driving of concentration difference. Increasing gas flow rate will weaken the unfavorable effect of diffusion, while more monolithic catalysts are required to guarantee CO oxidation efficiency. 4 Conclusion In summary, the excellent activity of Co3O4 nanorods at low temperature can be attributed to the robust vitality of abundant superoxide species (O2 −) on catalysts surface. As an intermediate, monodentate carbonate is formed by the reaction between CO and O2 −. Under this condition, the existence of water and CO2 would hinder the reactivity of O2- towards CO, thus leading to deactivation. At high temperature, CO is mainly oxidized by surface oxygen ion (O-) by forming bidentate carbonate intermediates. The difference of reaction pathways at low and high temperature may be ascribed to the variety of active oxygen species participated in CO oxidation which are hard to desorption at the given temperature. As an application, Co3O4 catalysts were integrated onto commercial metallic and cordierite monolithic substrates successfully by washcoating technique. The adhesive bonding of washcoat layer to the substrates was strong and had desirable resistance to ultrasonic vibration and thermal shock. The results of catalytic performance tests suggested that the metallic monolithic catalysts performed better CO oxidation activity under high gas flow, mainly because of superior heat conductivity ability and large surface area. The synthesized metallic monolithic catalysts exhibited 100% CO conversion stability in gases (25,000 h−1, 283.6 L/h) containing 5.6% H2O and 7% CO2 at 220 °C. While the gas hourly space velocity was over 25,000 h−1, the rapid decrease was observed in the CO conversing ascribed to the influence of large amount of H2O and CO2. Considering the outstanding catalytic activity and mechanical stability, the metallic monolithic catalysts proposed in this paper has the prospect for practical application. coredata.dc:description: Via investigating the evolution of carbonate intermediates by in-situ DRIFTS (25 °C–350 °C) analysis, temperature-dependent reaction pathways of CO oxidation over Co3O4 nanorods are successfully proposed. The types of reactive oxygen species participated in CO oxidation may affect the way CO react with neighboring oxygen atoms. Additionally, the negative effect of water and CO2 on the catalytic activity was also studied. Considering the remarkable reactivity towards CO, the Co3O4 catalysts were integrated onto metallic and cordierite monolithic substrates and used for CO conversion as application. SEM examinations show that the catalyst layer was coated on the substrates uniformly with few microcracks, and desirable mechanical shock and thermal shock resistance was observed. The influence of substrate materials, gas hourly space velocity, the existence of water vapor and CO2, and reaction time on the CO oxidation performance of monolithic catalysts was investigated. Metallic monolithic catalysts performed higher CO oxidation activity mainly owing to superior heat conductivity and larger surface area compared with cordierite monolithic catalysts. It is noticeable that superior activity was also achieved under high gas flow with the existence of H2O (5.6 vol.%) and CO2 (7 vol.%) at 220 °C, suggesting great promise for practical application.
coredata.dc:title: Temperature-dependent reaction pathways of CO oxidation and the application as monolithic catalysts for Co3O4 nanorods
